newsitem.title: USA: Kimberly-Clark says Scott Paper acquisition cuts income.
newsitem.headline: Kimberly-Clark says Scott Paper acquisition cuts income.

text.p: Kimberly-Clark Corp. on Monday reported slightly lower earnings for the second quarter, saying its results were hurt by the combination of Scott Paper Co.'s operations, which it acquired in 1995.
The company had net income of $363.5 million, or 65 cents per share, vs. $364.7 million, or 64 cents per share, in the second quarter of last year.
Sales fell 6.7 percent to $3.1 billion from $3.34 billion.
Following the news, Kimberly-Clark's stock lost $3.375 to $48.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said that, excluding the revenues from businesses sold last year to meet the regulatory requirements of its acquisition of Scott Paper, sales were down only 1 percent.
As part of Kimberly-Clark's $9.4 billion acquisition of Scott, which was completed in December 1995, the U.S. Justice Department required the company to sell off some assets.
"Operating profit was adversely affected by strategic changes related to the combination of Kimberly-Clark's and Scott Paper Co.'s away-from-home businesses in North America," the company said.

Sales of personal care products rose 10.6 percent to $1.33 billion in the second quarter, but tissue sales dropped 15.1 percent to $1.63 billion and newsprint and paper sales plummeted 28.5 percent to $176.8 million.
Kimberly-Clark said its personal care business should continue to perform well, particulary in North America and Latin America.
